title: Labour politician Andrew Adonis speaks about coming out as gay for the first time
text:
Labour politician Lord Andrew Adonis has spoken about his decision to come out as gay for the first time.

The 56-year-old, who served as secretary of state for transport under Gordon Brown and director of the No 10 policy unit for Tony Blair, said he decided to talk about his sexuality because “you should be completely honest and open in public about who you are”.

In 2015, Lord Adonis separated from his wife, Kathryn Davis, with whom he shares two children, after 21 years of marriage.

“I tried to suppress it, as did so many of my contemporaries,” he said.

“It was a big thing. Society has changed so much in the last 20 years. It’s a total revolution and I think it’s one for the better.”

Lord Adonis admitted that coming out as gay to his wife and children had been “very difficult”.

“It was a few years ago I came to terms with who I was,” he said.

“Lots of my contemporaries have had to come to terms with who they are and realise all those deeply held assumptions we had when we were teenagers and in our 20s no longer apply.”

Lord Adonis added that, “in the scale of things I had to deal with in my life, it was just one of them”.

Lord Adonis has long been a supporter of the LGBT+ community, championing a 2018 amendment to extend same-sex marriage and abortion rights to Northern Ireland in the House of Lords.

In a letter to then-prime minister Theresa May, he complained: “There is also growing anger and frustration that you have not made any adequate provision for parliament to safeguard basic rights in Northern Ireland in the absence of the Assembly… It is creating a deep sense of injustice, and lack of respect for rights in Northern Ireland.”

The politician joins a number of parliamentary figures who have come out as gay, lesbian or bisexual.

Maureen Colquhoun, who represented Labour in Northampton in the 1970s, was the UK’s first openly gay MP after she was outed by a tabloid newspaper. Colquhoun was later deselected by party members who said she had “blackened her image irredeemably”.

Lord Adonis’s fellow Labour peer, Lord Chris Smith, made history in 1984 when he said: “I’m Chris Smith, I’m the Labour MP for Islington South and Finsbury and I’m gay,” during a rally against Margaret Thatcher’s Section 28, which banned the so-called “promotion” of homosexuality in schools.
description: Labour politician Lord Andrew Adonis has spoken about his decision to come out as gay for the first time.
